Award.AbstractNarration:
The nation of Chile hosts many of the world's most important and productive astronomical facilities. Both Chile and the U.S. have a rich history of astronomy education outreach. The coordinated efforts undertaken by the 2016 Chile-U.S. Astronomy Education Outreach Summit will positively impact a large fraction of the Chilean population. Resources that result from this effort (e.g. Spanish-language astronomy education materials) can likely be transferred back to the U.S., where benefits can be realized in a growing Hispanic population. By encouraging a widespread appreciation of the many important roles that astronomy plays in Chile, these activities should help protect the U.S. investments in astronomy infrastructure in Chile, as well as enhance astronomy education in this country.

The 2016 Chile-U.S. Astronomy Education Outreach Summit is an effort lead by the major U.S. observatories in Chile and their management organizations. The goal is to improve astronomy education and public outreach (EPO) efforts in Chile, as well as EPO collaborations between institutions in Chile and the U.S. This proposal builds on the success and lessons learned from the first Chile-US Astronomy Education Outreach summit. The proposed March 2016 summit will bring together key stakeholders from all U.S. astronomy facilities in Chile and key Chilean stakeholder groups. It will focus on additional partnership opportunities and on the implementation of an action plan to address critical astronomy EPO needs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the next decade, over two-thirds of the world's telescope infrastructure will be located in Chile, representing billions of dollars of international collaboration and investment, and placing Chile on the world stage in this cutting-edge field of astronomy.

The United States and Chile have a long history of fruitful collaboration in astronomy going back to 1849 when U.S. Navy Lieutenant James Gillis established an observatory on Cerro Santa Lucia. And since that time, generations of Chilean and U.S. scientists, universities, and government agencies have worked together to increase our knowledge of the universe.

In 2015 and 2016, AUI in collaboration with AURA, GMTO, the U.S. Embassy in Chile, CONICYT, and Fundacion Imagen de Chile, with support from NSF, led the implementation of this project. The Summit effort over two years brought together more than 100 experts, representing nearly 50 Chilean and foreign institutions, to explore the state of astronomy education and outreach in Chile and between its international partners, as well as needs and opportunities for collaboration and coordination moving forward. The publication Reaching for the Stars: Findings of the Chile-U.S. Astronomy Education and Outreach Summit was a key result.

In November 2016, in a well-attended ceremony at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Santiago, Chile, Reaching for the Stars, was released, and the initiative was officially handed off to CONICYT. The document outlines the current state of astronomy education and outreach in Chile and between its international partners. In addition, Reaching for the Stars makes a number of key recommendations and identifies areas for future exploration. In the years that have followed the release of the document CONICYT has pushed forward with implementation of key recommendations, including the continuation of an annual meeting, bringing together Chilean and US astronomy educators and outreach professionals. In September 2017, what is now called the Chilean Network for Astronomy Education and Outreach (Red Chilena de la Educacion y Difusion de la Astronomia) held its first 3-day summit at CONICYT in Santiago, Chile. In September 2018, the meeting took place at University of Concepcion in Concepcion, Chile and focused on best practices in astronomy education and outreach in preparation for the 2019 and 2020 total solar eclipses in Chile.

Each year, the summit has grown in size and scope, and has deepened its roots in the Chilean astronomy EPO culture. The 2019 meeting is currently being planned and will take place in August in the south of Chile near the centerline of the 2020 solar eclipse. This NSF award supported participant travel for the 2016, 2017, and 2018 summits, as well as general meeting needs. The investment continues to result in growing collaboration in astronomy education and outreach in Chile, and between the US and Chile.
